entry.title: How to evaluate an idea of custom AI scenario for your business system like SAP S/4HANA Cloud in AI
entry.content:
SAP Business AI has listed all the  pre-delivered AI Scenarios for our business systems like SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Which means once we finished the initial setup like Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide, our end users can use the pre-delivered AI Scenarios.

In some situations, our business systems' users and other associates have some genius ideas to use LLM in the system. Then how to quickly evaluate the idea and the Effect of the idea? Give an example, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Outbound Delivery documents are create again Sales Orders, then the routes are  determined based on route determination logic. Are there any better options? For example, can we ask LLM to give some suggestions on routes based on more information like destinations' weather forecast, or even based on some freight charge information as grounding? I don't know yet. But I can quickly evaluate my idea With SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad before the developer starts to develop. 

Prerequisites:

  • SAP AI Core has been initially set up in your BTP Sub Account.
  • SAP AI Launchpad has been initially set up in your BTP Sub Account.

Steps:

1.  Prepare the data which can fetched from release API or  CDS View.  I have prepared data as the following:
{
    "DeliveryDocument": "80000000",
    "HeaderGrossWeight": "3.000",
    "HeaderNetWeight": "2.700",
    "HeaderWeightUnit": "KG",
    "HeaderVolume": "0.000",
    "HeaderVolumeUnit": "",
    "ShipFromAddress": { //from shop point address
        "CityName": "Palo Alto",
        "CompanyPostalCode": "",
        "CorrespondenceLanguage": "EN",
        "Country": "US",
        "EmailAddress": "",
        "FaxNumber": "",
        "FaxNumberExtension": "",
        "Floor": "",
        "FormOfAddress": "0003",
        "HomeCityName": "",
        "HouseNumber": "3475",
        "HouseNumberSupplementText": "",
        "MobilePhoneNumber": "",
        "PhoneNumber": "",
        "PostalCode": "94304-1355",
        "PrfrdCommMediumType": "",
        "Region": "CA",
        "RoomNumber": "",
        "StreetName": "Deer Creek",
        "StreetPrefixName": "",
        "StreetSuffixName": "",
        "TaxJurisdiction": "GA00000000"
    },
        "ShipToAddress": {   //from ship to party address
        "DeliveryDocument": "80000000",
        "PartnerFunction": "SP",
        "AddressID": "22900",
        "BusinessPartnerName1": "Domestic US Customer 1",
        "AddressTimeZone": "EST",
        "CityName": "Atlanta",
        "CompanyPostalCode": "",
        "CorrespondenceLanguage": "EN",
        "Country": "US",
        "EmailAddress": "mrinal.kanti.chanda@sap.com",
        "FaxNumber": "",
        "FaxNumberExtension": "",
        "Floor": "",
        "FormOfAddress": "0003",
        "HomeCityName": "",
        "HouseNumber": "200",
        "HouseNumberSupplementText": "",
        "MobilePhoneNumber": "",
        "PhoneNumber": "999 555 6721",
        "PostalCode": "30315-1402",
        "PrfrdCommMediumType": "",
        "Region": "GA",
        "RoomNumber": "",
        "StreetName": "Augusta Ave SE",
        "StreetPrefixName": "",
        "StreetSuffixName": "",
        "TaxJurisdiction": "GA00000000"
    }
}

 

2.  Test in SAP AI Launchpad:

I prepared the follow Sytem prompt:

You are an expert of logistic.You have received a user's outbound delivery information in JSON. The user need you to suggest a best route based outbound delivery JSON information.

 The User Prompt is the JSON file in Step 1 .

Let's test in SAP AI Launchpad with GPT-4.1.

The following is the response from GPT-4.1

Based on your outbound delivery JSON, hereâ€™s your **delivery scenario**:

- **Ship From:** 3475 Deer Creek, Palo Alto, CA 94304-1355
- **Ship To:** 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, GA 30315-1402
- **Weight:** 3.0 kg (Net: 2.7 kg)
- **Country:** US (Domestic shipment)
- **Time Zone Difference:** Palo Alto (Pacific) â†’ Atlanta (Eastern)
- **No special volume requirement or hazardous cargo flagged**

---

## Best Route Suggestion

### 1. **Route Options Overview**

#### **A. Air Freight**
- **Best for:** Speed (overnight or 1-2 day delivery)
- **Cost:** Highest (but the shipment weight is low, so the cost is manageable)
- **Process:**
  - Pickup from Palo Alto
  - Deliver to SFO, OAK, or SJC airport
  - Direct flight to ATL
  - Local delivery in Atlanta

#### **B. Ground Courier (Expedited)**
- **Best for:** Fast and reliable ground service (2-3 days typical with express)
- **Carriers:** FedEx, UPS, USPS Priority Express, DHL
- **Cost:** Lower than air freight, still fast for lightweight parcels

#### **C. Ground Courier (Standard)**
- **Best for:** Cost efficiency, less urgency (4-6 days)
- **Carriers:** FedEx Ground, UPS Ground, USPS Priority

---

### 2. **Recommended (Best) Route for Your Delivery**

Given your shipment details (very light, no hazardous/volume concerns), and typical business shipping needs:

#### **FedEx/UPS/DHL Express Air Service**
1. **Pickup:** Arrange for parcel pickup at 3475 Deer Creek, Palo Alto, CA.
2. **Transport:** 
   - Collected and sent same day to a regional hub (San Francisco/Oakland/San Jose for air departure).
   - Overnight air transport to Atlanta Hartsfield International Airport.
3. **Delivery:** 
   - Early-morning or same-day handoff for final-mile delivery in Atlanta.
   - Will reach consignee at 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, within 24-36 hours.

**Features:**
- **Tracking & Signature**: Included.
- **Best for:** Business-critical, customer satisfaction.
- **Estimated Delivery Time:** Next business day or 2 business days.
- **Estimated Cost:** Moderate (due to low parcel weight).

---

### 3. **Alternative: Ground Courier Service**

If premium speed is not critical:

- **FedEx Ground, UPS Ground, or USPS Priority Mail**
- Delivery estimate: 4-6 business days
- Pickup same as above, direct line haul across the US
- Cost: Lower

---

## **Suggested Carrier and Service**

- **Carrier:** FedEx, UPS, or DHL Express (all ideal for coast-to-coast shipments)
- **Service:** FedEx Priority Overnight, UPS Next Day Air Saver, or DHL Express Worldwide
- **Booking:** You can book online, arrange for pickup, label your parcel at origin. Given the low weight, most shipping managers select air express for coast-to-coast in the US.

---

### **Route Mapping Summary**

```
1. Palo Alto, CA (your facility)
      â†“
2. SFO/SJC/OAK Airport (CA hub, air transfer)
      â†“
3. ATL Airport (GA hub, air arrival)
      â†“
4. Atlanta last-mile depot
      â†“
5. 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, GA (customer)
```

---

## **Action Steps**
- Package and label your shipment.
- Get quotes from FedEx, UPS, DHL online or through your logistics provider for **air express service**.
- Book for next day pickup/drop-off.
- Share tracking with your customer.

**Note:** If your delivery is not time-critical or if budget is the priority, use a ground service instead, accepting the longer transit time.

---

**Do you need carrier recommendations, rate estimation, or step-by-step booking guidance?** Let me know how I can specifically assist next!

Of course, you can adjust the prompt or even you grounding some document information in AI Launchpad.

If the result is acceptable, then Architecture can design. Then the developer can start to realize back end with CAP NodeJS, CAP Java, RAP(Cloud ABAP), Python. The listed Languages are supported by the SAP AI SDK.

The end!

Thanks for your time!

Jacky Liu

entry.title: Invoking LLM from Cloud Integration Responsibly â€“ Made Easy with Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core
entry.content:
In this blog post, Iâ€™ll walk you through how to seamlessly invoke large language models (LLMs) from Cloud Integration using the Generative AI Hub and the Orchestration Workflow API in SAP AI Core. Weâ€™ll focus on building a GDPR-compliant automation flow that leverages data masking and pseudonymisation to ensure privacy while still delivering value from generative AI.

The scenario we'll explore simulates a real-world use case: when a Business Partner record is updated in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, a personalized email notification is generated by an LLM and automatically sent out via Cloud Integration.

Thanks to prebuilt orchestration capabilities of Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, such as templating, I/O filtering, and data masking, the process of generating compliant LLM responses can be achieved with just a single API call.

â€ƒ

Before diving into the implementation steps, letâ€™s take a closer look at the process flow behind this sample scenario.

Process Flow (Steps)

  1. Business Partner Update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
    A user creates or edits a Business Partner record in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Event Triggered and Message Sent to SAP AEM
    The system triggers an event and sends a message to SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM).
  3. Cloud Integration iFlow Subscribes and Starts Processing
    The CPI iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and begins processing as soon as a new message is published.
  4. Retrieve Old Payload from CAP Application
    The iFlow queries the CAP application to retrieve the previous version (old payload) of the Business Partner record from SAP HANA Cloud.
  5. Call the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core for AI-Based Email Generation
    With both the old and new payloads in hand, the iFlow invokes the Generative AI Hub using the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core to generate a personalized email body in HTML format. Here, a predefined orchestration pipeline applies data masking, prompt templating, and foundation model invocation to generate a compliant, personalised email body â€“ without exposing any sensitive data.
  6. Send Email to Business Partner
    The iFlow sends the generated email to the Business Partnerâ€™s email address via a standard mail adapter in Cloud Integration, completing the end-to-end notification process.

As part of this blog, I will not focus on connectivity between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Advanced Event Mesh (steps 1 and 2). For a live step-by-step demonstration of the setup, please review this video: ğŸ‘‰ SAP Tech Bytes: Configuring SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Configuring Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core

Orchestration in SAP AI Core is a managed service that enables unified access, control, and execution of generative AI models through standardized APIs, templating, and configurable AI workflow components.

In our scenario, we will utilize it to chain together prebuilt steps, such as data masking and foundation model invocation, to generate a personalized email body in HTML format via a single API call.

To access the Orchestration service in SAP AI Core, you need to set up Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad. Please refer to either of the following resources for setup instructions:

  • SAP Discovery Mission: Set Up SAP AI Core Generative AI Hub
  • SAP Developer Center Tutorial: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - Setup

Before moving to the next step, please ensure that your orchestration configuration is deployed and is in the RUNNING status.

Building the Orchestration Workflow

In this example, we will build the orchestration workflow for the event of Business Partner change.

Within SAP AI Launchpad, navigate to Generative AI Hub -> Orchestration and click Edit Workflow to select the workflow steps you require.

For our scenario, deselect the Input Translation and Output Translation steps, as they are not needed.

In the Templating step, we define prompts that guide LLM on how to perform its task.

We configure two types of messages for our scenario:

  • System Prompt
  • User Prompt

The system prompt defines the overall behavior, tone, and role of the LLM. It sets global instructions that remain consistent across requests, ensuring predictable formatting and response style.

For our use case, the system prompt will instruct the LLM to act as a multilingual assistant that compares old and new Business Partner profiles and generates a compliant email.

You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".
Instructions:
- Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
- Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
- Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
- Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
- Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
- Do not generate the email subject line, only the body.

The user prompt provides the dynamic, task-specific input for each request. Here, we pass actual data: the old profile payload, new profile payload, and target language. These placeholders will be replaced at runtime to generate personalized content.

Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}
Here is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}
Here is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}

 

In the Data Masking step, we can anonymize or pseudonymize personally identifiable information from the input for selected entities. For our scenario, we will select the Pseudonymization option. This will substitute personally identifiable information in selected categories with a MASKED_ENTITY_ID placeholder and allow us to unmask the LLM response before returning it to the Sender.

The Input Filtering step allows you to apply content safety filters to the incoming data before invoking the foundation model.

In the Model Configuration step, we can select the desired model (e.g., GPT-4.1) and configure relevant parameters such as temperature, token limits, etc.

Finally, the Output Filtering step enables content safety filtering on the LLM-generated response to ensure compliance and prevent undesired content.

Once the orchestration workflow is configured, you can inspect its JSON definition and download it locally. This definition will be used later when invoking the orchestration workflow via API from Cloud Integration.

Additionally, you can test the orchestration inference directly within SAP AI Launchpad by providing sample input variables. The testing tool allows you to view and trace the LLM response and fine-tune the workflow configuration as needed.

When inspecting the output payload, you can clearly trace the results of each orchestration step â€“ such as Input Masking, Output Unmasking, Input Filtering, and Output Filtering.

To learn more about Orchestration in SAP AI Core, refer to the SAP Developer Center Tutorials: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - orchestration.

Configure SAP Cloud Integration Business Partner Notification iFlow

Now that we have our SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, and the Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core configured, we can proceed with the Cloud Integration iFlow configuration.

This iFlow ensures that Business Partner changes trigger compliant AI-generated email notifications, while maintaining data consistency in HANA Cloud. It leverages SAP Advanced Event Mesh, CAP, and Generative AI Hub for an automated end-to-end process.

High-Level iFlow Overview

  • Triggered by AEM Queue when a new event is published.
  • Retrieves BP details from S/4HANA Cloud.
  • (If event is BP update) Fetches old BP payload from HANA Cloud (via CAP service).
  • Invokes the Orchestration Workflow API to compare old vs. new payloads and generate an HTML email content while ensuring that no sensitive information is passed to LLM.
  • Upserts updated BP details into SAP HANA Cloud via CAP service.
  • Sends an email to the Business Partner.

Step-by-Step Process Breakdown

  1. Event Trigger
    • The iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and processes incoming events.
  2. Retrieve Business Partner Details
    • An OData request is sent to SAP S/4HANA Cloud to fetch the latest BP details.
    • Key parameters (e.g., BP ID, BP email) are extracted and saved into the properties for further processing.
  3. Map to CAP Format
    • BP details are transformed into the CAP service data model.
    • The new payload is stored in XML and JSON format for further use.
  4. Conditional Logic
    • BP creation â†’ No old payload is retrieved.
    • BP update â†’ Old payload is retrieved for comparison.
  5. Retrieve Old Payload from HANA Cloud (BP update only)
    • The iFlow calls the CAP service to fetch the previous BP record. Please refer to the GitHub repository businesspartner_srv for more information on the CAP service. In our scenario, the CAP service acts as an intermediary that retrieves old Business Partner data from SAP HANA Cloud, provides an OData service for data access, and enables the upsert of updated details.
  6. AI-Based Email Generation
    • A subprocess calls the Orchestration Workflow API via the AI adapter to create a personalized HTML email body in a GDPR-compliant way.
  7. Upsert BP Details in HANA Cloud
    • The updated BP details are upserted into SAP HANA Cloud via the CAP service.
  8. Send Email
    • The iFlow sends an email using the Mail Adapter.

You can find this iFlow as a ZIP archive here: AEM_GenAI_BPMailGenerator_blog.zip

For this blog, weâ€™ll take a closer look at Step #6, where the AI Receiver Adapter is used to invoke the Orchestration Workflow API configured in the previous section.

1) In our case, the easiest way to prepare a payload for the AI Receiver Adapter is by using a small Groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

Message processData(Message message) {
    def map = message.getProperties()

    def createBP = map.get("EventType").toString() == "sap.s4.beh.businesspartner.v1.BusinessPartner.Created.v1" ? true : false

    // Dynamic user template
    def userText = createBP
        ? "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"
        : "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"

    def userTemplate = [
        role: "user",
        content: [
            [
                type : "text",
                text : userText
            ]
        ]
    ]

    def systemText = createBP
        ? """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to generate a warm, professional welcome email for a newly created Business Partner profile based on the provided NEW profile payload.

        Instructions:
        - Welcome the Business Partner.
        - Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
        - Mention that their profile has been successfully created.
        - Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
        - Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
        - Keep it concise and clear.
        - Keep the tone friendly, professional, and approachable.
        - End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
        - Do not generate the email subject line, only the body."""
        
        : """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".

        Instructions:
        - Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
        - Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
        - Keep it concise and clear.
        - Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
        - Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
        - Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
        - Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
        - End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
        - Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
        - Do not generate the email subject line, only the body."""

    def systemTemplate = [
        role: "system",
        content: [
            [
                type : "text",
                text : systemText
            ]
        ]
    ]
    
    def language = map.get("language")
    def newPayload = map.get("new_payload_json")
    
    def inputParams = [
        language_name: language,
        new_payload: newPayload instanceof String ? newPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(newPayload)
    ]
    
    if (!createBP) {
        def oldPayload = map.get("old_payload_json")
        inputParams.old_payload = oldPayload instanceof String ? oldPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(oldPayload)
    }


    // Build the JSON structure
    def payload = [
        orchestration_config: [
            module_configurations: [
                llm_module_config: [
                    model_name: "gpt-4.1",
                    model_params: [
                        frequency_penalty: 0,
                        presence_penalty: 0,
                        max_completion_tokens: 24576,
                        temperature: 1
                    ],
                    model_version: "2025-04-14"
                ],
                templating_module_config: [
                    template: [
                        userTemplate,
                        systemTemplate
                    ],
                    defaults: [:]
                ],
                filtering_module_config: [
                    input : [
                        filters: [
                            [
                                type: "azure_content_safety",
                                config: [
                                    Hate: 2,
                                    SelfHarm: 2,
                                    Sexual: 2,
                                    Violence: 2,
                                    PromptShield: true
                                ]
                            ]
                        ]
                    ],
                    output: [
                        filters: [
                            [
                                type  : "azure_content_safety",
                                config: [
                                    Hate: 2,
                                    SelfHarm: 2,
                                    Sexual: 2,
                                    Violence: 2
                                ]
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ],
                masking_module_config: [
                    masking_providers: [
                        [
                            type: "sap_data_privacy_integration",
                            method: "pseudonymization",
                            entities: [
                                [type: "profile-credit-card-number"],
                                [type: "profile-driverlicense"],
                                [type: "profile-email"],
                                [type: "profile-sensitive-data"],
                                [type: "profile-ethnicity"],
                                [type: "profile-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-pronouns-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-iban"],
                                [type: "profile-location"],
                                [type: "profile-nationalid"],
                                [type: "profile-nationality"],
                                [type: "profile-org"],
                                [type: "profile-passport"],
                                [type: "profile-person"],
                                [type: "profile-phone"],
                                [type: "profile-political-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-public"],
                                [type: "profile-religious-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-internal"],
                                [type: "profile-ssn"],
                                [type: "profile-sexual-orientation"],
                                [type: "profile-trade-union"],
                                [type: "profile-address"],
                                [type: "profile-url"],
                                [type: "profile-university"],
                                [type: "profile-username-password"]
                            ],
                            mask_grounding_input: [enabled: false],
                            allowlist: []
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            ]
        ],
        input_params: inputParams
    ]

    // Serialize to JSON string
    def jsonString = JsonOutput.toJson(payload)
    message.setBody(jsonString)

    return message
}

This script constructs the payload expected by the Orchestration API of SAP AI Core.

Note that the settings within the module_configurations block match the configuration that you downloaded from SAP AI Launchpad.

2) To set up a Connection to our AI Core Orchestration deployment, we first need to configure a Security Material.
In your SAP BTP Cockpit and access the service key of the SAP AI Core (extended plan) service instance created earlier.

Create an OAuth2 Client Credentials Security Material with:

  • Token Service URL: url from the service key + â€œ/oauth/tokenâ€
  • Client ID: clientid from the service key
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from the service key

On the Connection tab of the AI Receiver Adapter:

  • Set the Address to the AI_API_URL from the service key.
  • Reference the Security Material in the OAuth2 Client Credentials field.

On the Processing tab:

  • Set Request Payload Source to â€œExchange Bodyâ€.
  • Provide the Orchestration Deployment ID and AI Resource Group from SAP AI Launchpad.

3) JSON output is converted into XML for further processing.

4) Content Modifier step is used to extract the email_body from the Orchestration API response via the XPath expression: /root/orchestration_result/choices/message/content

Testing the Scenario End-to-End

With all components configured, itâ€™s time to put the setup to the test.

ğŸ“½ï¸ Watch Event-Driven Business Partner Email Notification Demo 

The video walks through the entire process â€“ showing the change in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the processing inside Cloud Integration, and the final email received by the Business Partner.

Conclusion

This scenario highlights how simple and seamless it is to invoke SAP AI Core from Cloud Integration to generate compliant, human-sounding content.

With just a small Groovy script to prepare the payload, CPI can call an SAP AI Core Orchestration Workflow directly via the AI Receiver Adapter â€“ without complex custom coding or middleware. All compliance safeguards, such as data masking and filtering, are handled by the orchestration workflow, ensuring that no sensitive information is ever sent to the LLM.

The result is an automated, end-to-end process where a Business Partner update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud triggers an event, CPI processes it, SAP AI Core generates the compliant email body, and the recipient is informed â€“ all with minimal configuration effort.

This pattern can be applied to other master data objects and backend systems, as well as to any scenario where Cloud Integration must securely generate AI-based content â€” making it a powerful blueprint for scaling compliant AI adoption across the enterprise.

entry.title: Stop AI Model Disasters: The Application Owner's Guide to Bulletproof Deployments
entry.content:
Co-Author: Lukas PÃ¤tz

So, you've deployed a fantastic application, leveraging the power of SAPâ€˜s Generative AI Hub (linked reference architecture)! That's a significant step towards building intelligent business processes.

As a quick reminder: SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub is part of the AI Foundation. SAPâ€™s AI Foundation, similar to an operating system provides the means to build, extend, and run custom AI solutions and agents at scale. It includes the generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, which is a rich set of AI capabilities (40+ frontier AI models, orchestration, SDKs, etc.), for productive purpose, running on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

Your application runs on BTP, and LLM technology powers the intelligence behind it. But here's what you can't delegate: managing the LLMâ€™s Lifecycle for your application.

 

Understanding Model Lifecycle: A Key Distinction

Before diving into the model lifecycle, let's clarify the different ways you can leverage AI models:

  • Your self-hosted Models: You bring your own models (e.g., fine-tuned open-source models, proprietary models) and deploy them. This is akin to a Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) offering, where you manage the model artifacts, their dependencies, and their whole lifecycle on your own.  This gives you maximum flexibility: you can select, customize, and optimize models to fit your exact needs, including full control over versioning and performance. However, with that freedom comes responsibility. Youâ€™re in charge of the full lifecycle â€” from infrastructure and scaling to security, compliance, monitoring, costs and updates.
  • SAP Managed Models: This is comparable to a Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) offering. The Generative AI Hub provides pre-integrated, managed access to various LLMs from leading providers (i.e Azure OpenAI GPT-5, Google Gemini 2.5 Pro, AWS Claude Sonnet 4, etc.). It's important to understand that you do not need to acquire separate licenses for these LLMs; SAP handles the commercial agreements and technical integration. Furthermore, SAP takes on the responsibility for data privacy and security or confidentiality standards, related to the LLMs consumed through the Generative AI Hub, significantly reducing your operational burden.

For the following we focus on the latter. LLMs, the powerful engines behind generative AI, are constantly evolving. Model providers release new versions, older versions might be retired, and factors like performance and cost can change, as indicated by the graphic below. This dynamic environment means that the specific LLM version your application relies on today might not be available tomorrow.

 

Why Does This Matter to You, the Application Owner?

Here's the reality: AI models get retired. Your application depends on them. Without a lifecycle management strategy, you're one model retirement away from downtime â€”and missing out on better quality from newer models.

Moreover, different model versions may offer significantly better performance. A newer model might produce more accurate summaries which can directly impact your application's quality, user satisfaction, and business outcomes. Not updating could mean missing out on substantial improvements in capability, efficiency, or cost-effectiveness.

Your Role: Stay Informed, Be Prepared

Your primary responsibility regarding the model lifecycle is to:

  • Stay informed about the models supported by the SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub, including their versions, capabilities, cost, and most importantly, their retirement dates.
  • Have a plan for upgrading your application's model configuration when necessary.

Let's have a look on how you can fulfill these responsibilities using the tools and information available.

Staying Informed: Where to Find Model Information

SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub provides several ways to discover and understand the available LLMs:

  • SAP Notes:

    The central source of truth for supported models is SAP Note 3437766. This note provides comprehensive information, including the list of available models, supported versions, token conversion rates, rate limits, and retirement dates. Regularly checking this note is essential. You can access it via https://me.sap.com/notes/3437766. Crucially, you can subscribe to this SAP Note (indicated by the star icon) to receive automatic notifications via email about any changes, ensuring you're always up-to-date.

  • SAP AI Launchpad (UI):

    It's the natural place for an application owner to explore the Model Library and discover available models and their details. The Model Library also supports through comparison functionalities like the Leaderboard tab. Here you can see similar or better performing models.

  • Discovery API Endpoint:

    For programmatic access or detailed inspection, you can use the discovery API endpoint. By sending a GET request to the {{apiurl}}/v2/lm/scenarios/{scenarioid}/models endpoint, you can retrieve a list of all available models, their versions, capabilities, and retirement dates. This is a powerful tool for checking information dynamically. Find further information about that on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

By utilizing these resources, you can proactively identify when the model your application relies on is approaching its retirement date and plan your next steps.

Taking Action: Upgrading Your Model

When it's time to switch to a newer model version (preceded by tests/benchmarks), you have two main strategies, decided during the initial deployment configuration:

  • Auto Upgrade (modelVersion: latest):

    • How it works: When you create your generative AI configuration for a specific LLM, either through orchestration API or as a deployment, you can set the modelVersion parameter to latest. This will automatically use the most recent version of the specified model that is supported.
    • Pros: Less manual effort. As we support newer versions, your deployment will automatically shift, potentially giving you access to model improvements without intervention.
    • Cons: Less control. Your application might suddenly start using a new model version which, although intended to be compatible, could introduce subtle changes in behavior or performance that you haven't explicitly tested. This can be particularly problematic if your application relies on consistent LLM output behavior. Furthermore, it won't help in the situation of moving to different models (i.e. GPT-4.1 to GPT-5).

  • Manual Upgrade (Specify <modelVersion>):

    • How it works: When creating your orchestration configuration, you specify a particular modelVersion, like "2024-05-13". When this specific version is close to retirement, you will need to:
      1. Select a suitable newer model version based on your benchmarks using the SAP Note, Discovery API and/or UI.
      2. Via our harmonized API in orchestration, it is easy for you to change your configuration to a newer, specific model version.

        And only if you handle your custom defined endpoint:

      3. Patch upgrade your existing deployment to the configurationId you created newly.
    • Pros: Full control. You decide exactly which model version your application uses and when to make the change, allowing for thorough testing beforehand. This is especially important for production systems where behavioral changes in LLMs can have significant impacts.
    • Cons: More manual effort. You must actively monitor retirement dates and perform the upgrade steps yourself.

Choosing Your Strategy: Best Practices

The best strategy depends on your application's needs for stability versus automatically receiving updates.

For most production applications, especially those sensitive to potential behavioral changes in LLMs, specifying a fixed modelVersion (Manual Upgrade) has emerged as a best practice. While it requires more manual effort, it provides the necessary control and predictability. Most application owners prefer not to use the latest parameter due to the risk of unexpected behavior shifts with new LLM versions. By fixing the version, you safeguard against such changes and can plan updates proactively.

If stability and controlled changes are paramount, opt for Manual Upgrade by specifying a fixed modelVersion and plan for scheduled updates. This allows you to thoroughly test new model versions in a controlled environment before deploying them to production.

If minimizing operational overhead and automatically getting the latest model version is preferred for non-critical or exploratory applications, use Auto Upgrade with modelVersion: latest. However, remain aware that behavior might change with new versions and you need to change from model to model.

 

In Summary

As an application owner, understanding and managing the LLM model lifecycle is key to your application's longevity and reliability.

  • Regularly consult SAP Note 3437766 and/or the Discovery API (or the UI) to track model versions and retirement dates. Remember to subscribe to the SAP Note for automated updates.
  • Choose an appropriate upgrade strategy (latest for automatic updates or specifying a modelVersion for manual control) when setting up your configuration and deployment. For production scenarios, specifying a fixed modelVersion is generally recommended as a best practice.
  • If using manual upgrades, proactively change your configuration within orchestration and if custom deployment is used you need to patch/upgrade the current model version before it expires.

By staying informed and prepared, you can ensure your generative AI application continues to deliver value seamlessly, leveraging the latest innovations from the SAPâ€™s Generative AI Hub.

We recommend keeping a close eye on the What's new section for upcoming release announcements and implementation guidance.

 

â€ƒ

entry.title: Building a RAG Bot on SAP BTP With Hana Cloud Vector Engine and AI Core
entry.content:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a method for improving the output of large language models (LLMs). While LLMs are trained on vast amounts of data, they may lack access to proprietary or enterprise-specific information behind paywalls, or other custom data needed to generate accurate results. RAG supplements the LLMâ€™s knowledge by retrieving relevant external information, making its outputs more accurate, relevant, and useful in a cost-effective way.

Key Challenges of LLMs Solved by RAG Bots

  • Presenting False Information: LLMs can hallucinate when they lack the correct answer, often providing inaccurate responses that may appear convincing, which can lead to wrong decisions.
  • Outdated Responses: LLMs are essentially prediction machines, generating answers based on their training data. As a result, they may provide outdated information if it falls beyond their knowledge cutoff.
  • Terminology Differences: Natural languages like English, Spanish, or French are subjective, and the same term can have multiple meanings. LLMs may misunderstand context, leading to incorrect answers.

RAG bots address these challenges by supplementing LLMs with relevant, up-to-date information, making them a cost-effective and reliable way to enhance AI outputs.

To complete this project we will need

  • Data not already accessible to the LLM: Thereâ€™s no point in using widely known content, like Shakespeareâ€™s plays, as the LLM likely already knows it.
  • A Vector Database: In this example, weâ€™ll use SAP HANA Vector Engine. Many options exist, including AWS vector engines and open-source alternatives. choose the one that fits your needs.
  • A Python Environment: All code will be implemented in Python.
  • An Embedding Model: Here, we use OpenAIâ€™s embedding model, but any freely available model from Hugging Face or similar sources works.

What is a vector database? why do i need it? how does it differ from a real database?

Vector databases store data as mathematical representations called embeddings. Imagine visiting an ice cream shop youâ€™ve been to a hundred times. On your 101st visit, a super-intelligent shopkeeper could instantly guess your preferred flavor based on your previous questions. Thatâ€™s similar to how a vector database works.

Each piece of data is stored as an embedding, and when you ask a question, itâ€™s converted into an embedding as well. The database then finds the part of your data that is most similar to your query. For example, if your question is meant to return the number 6, and the 12th paragraph of the 200th PDF is embedded as 5.8989898, the database will return it because itâ€™s the closest match.

Itâ€™s crucial to embed information carefully. Using inaccurate data or poor embedding methods can result in irrelevant or excessive information being retrieved.

What are embeddings?
An embedding is a vector representation of data generated by an embedding model. In our setup, the model creates embeddings for your data, which are then stored in the HANA vector database. When you ask a question, it is also converted into an embedding, and the database compares it against the stored embeddings to find the most relevant matches.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

What vector embeddings looks like

 

start:

For my data i used this . It is a long 2000 page pdf on aws lambda.

First install these dependencies in your terminal

python-dotenv==1.0.1 # For reading environment variables stored in .env file
langchain==0.2.2
langchain-community==0.2.3
unstructured==0.14.4 # Document loading
# onnxruntime==1.17.1 # chromadb dependency: on Mac use `conda install onnxruntime -c conda-forge`
# For Windows users, install Microsoft Visual C++ Build Tools first
# install onnxruntime before installing `chromadb`

Then import the following before proceeding

 

Step 1: Document Loading

At this point we have our database ready and we have set up our aicore model appropriately; now we can import our document.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Step 2: Splitting the documents

This is a crucial stage because how you split and chunk your documents directly affects the quality of results. Dividing documents into manageable segments allows the system to efficiently create accurate embeddings. When queried, these embeddings produce more precise responses.

Each chunk can also be enriched with metadata, such as page numbers or chapter titles. This helps locate the source if a deeper look is needed. Chunking must be done thoughtfully by headings, topics, or other logical divisions to ensure the system captures the content effectively.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Step 3: Connect to database:

At this stage, we are ready to generate the embeddings and connect them to our HANA database or any other vector database we choose to use.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

There are many resources on how to connect to hana, so for now i will leave this here.

Step 4: Access Embedding Model:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

As explained earlier, an embedding model transforms complex, high-dimensional data into numerical values that machines can easily understand. This makes the data easier to process and allows ML models to identify patterns and relationships.

A vector is a one-dimensional representation of data containing multiple values. For example, a weather vector might be [2, 32, 1000], representing rain (2 = yes), temperature (32Â°F), and location (1000 = a specific county). Vectors capture relevant information depending on the type of data being represented.

Since this is a text embedding model, it can only create embeddings for textual data. This is important if you want to embed image files etc.

Step 4: Adding Data into HANA.

First, create the schema. You can do this by running a SQL query with the desired schema. This schema will hold the table where all your embeddings are stored.

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

This code will create the table in your database, load your document, split it into chunks, and generate embeddings for each chunk.

When querying the data, your query is first transformed into an embedding and placed in the vector space. The vector database then returns the document chunks that are most similar to your query. This is why chunking is important: it ensures that the system can match your prompt accurately, typically using cosine similarity to find the closest matches.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

After integrating everything into a clean Streamlit UI, here is the final result.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Thanks for reading.

entry.title: Getting started with Prompt Templating in SAP Generative AI Hub: Principles and Implementation
entry.content:
In enterprise AI, prompts are everything. A well-crafted prompt can unlock context-aware, high-quality responses, while a poorly structured one can lead to irrelevant or inconsistent outputs. But scaling prompt engineering across business scenarios requires more than creativity - it needs structure, governance, and reusability.
This is where prompt templating in the SAP Generative AI Hub comes in.

In this blog, weâ€™ll first explore the principles and lifecycle of prompt templating and then walk through an example implementation using Generative AI Hub SDK in python.

What is Prompt Templating?

Prompt templating is the practice of designing prompts with reusable structures where certain elements are parameterized. Instead of hardcoding values, you define placeholders that get filled dynamically at runtime

For example:

 

Here, {{complaint_text}} is a placeholder. At runtime, the system replaces it with the actual input, making the template reusable across multiple use cases.

Why Prompt Templating Matters

In enterprises, scaling prompts without templating can be chaotic. Hereâ€™s why templating is essential:

1. Reusability - One template, infinite use cases.
2. Consistency - Standardized responses across users, teams, and apps.
3. Governance - Store, version, and audit prompts in a registry.
4. Flexibility - Easily adapt prompts to different scenarios without rewriting logic.

Before we move on the principles letâ€™s look at a high-level flow of the lifecycle of prompt templating.

The lifecycle of prompt templating can be summarized in five simple steps:

  1. Design a template with placeholders (e.g., {{customer_name}}, {{text}}).
  2. Fill placeholders with runtime values.
  3. Send the finalized prompt to the LLM.
  4. Capture and return the model response.

 

 

Key Principles of Effective Prompt Templating

When designing prompt templates, keep these guiding principles in mind:

1. Parameterize Inputs

Identify which parts of your prompt will change and make them variables.

  • Example: {{customer_name}}, {{invoice_number}}
  • Tip: Use meaningful variable names so the intent is always clear.
 2. Follow Instructional Patterns

LLMs perform best when instructions are clear, explicit, and structured.

  • State the task directly (e.g., â€œSummarize in 3 bullet pointsâ€).
  • Provide examples if needed to guide the modelâ€™s behavior.
3. Plan for Error Handling

Not all inputs will be perfect. Templates should anticipate edge cases.

  • Define fallback instructions (e.g., â€œIf information is missing, respond with â€˜Insufficient detailsâ€™.â€).
  • Validate inputs before filling them into prompts.

Implementation of Prompt templating using in Python using SAP generative AI Hub

Before we begin, make sure you have:

  • Access to SAP AI Core.
  • SAP Generative AI Hub SDK installed (Python) .
  • A registered LLM deployment available in your AI Core tenant.

 

Steps

  • Open your Jupyter/VS Code notebook.
  • Import orchestration models from the SDK.
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.message import SystemMessage, UserMessage
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.template import Template, TemplateValue
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.llm import LLM
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.models.config import OrchestrationConfig
from gen_ai_hub.orchestration.service import OrchestrationService
  • Define a template for your task (translation, summarization, classification, etc.).
template = Template(
    messages=[
        SystemMessage("You are a helpful customer support assistant."),
        UserMessage("Summarize this complaint into a polite response: {{?complaint_text}}")
    ]
)
  • Pick the LLM (already deployed in AI Core).
llm = LLM(name="gpt-4o", version="latest", parameters={"max_tokens": 100})
  • Configure orchestration.
config = OrchestrationConfig(template=template, llm=llm)
orchestration_service = OrchestrationService(config=config)

print(result.orchestration_result.choices[0].message.content)
  • Run inference by passing dynamic inputs.
  • Get structured, predictable outputs from the model.

Further resources:

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core/sap-ai-core-service-guide/use-prompt-template
  • https://btp-ai-bp.docs.sap/docs/technical-view/generative-ai/plain/prompt-templating

entry.title: AI-driven, Joule-enabled Warehouse Resource & Operations Management for SAP EWM on S/4 HANA 2023
entry.content:
It is a topic in every warehouse: Supervisors and Warehouse Operations Managers would like to see their planned workload for the day and see in real-time whether shipping times will be met. If shipping times are in jeopardy, the warehouse system is then expected to evaluate if an optimized resource allocation could pro-actively solve any potential delays. When a more optimal usage of the available resources is found, resources should automatically be directed to the critical areas. Being able to take action proactively is of the essence, because we do not want to only take action when we are already in delay.

The following is an example of an AI-driven, Joule enabled Application that can accomplish the above outlined requirements and activities supported by AI. The Application leverages the embedded AI in the EWM Private Cloud Edition S/4 HANA 2023 FPS03 release and the Joule Studio available in SAP Build.

 

 

The Architecture of the Application looks as follows:

 

AI-based Warehouse Workload Visibility

In the current version of the Application, the expected workloads of picking and packing operations are calculated leveraging the embedded AI capabilities in SAP EWM, which are then displayed in the UI5 Application (see in the example below):

It is also clearly visible in which Activity Area the workload is currently exceeding the planned Resource capacity.

The Application then further allows a manual simulation of adding or removing Resources to evaluate the impact in a given activity area. 

The fully "automatic rebalancing" function evaluates whether it is possible to optimize the resource allocation to the different areas, considering the allowed resource types in an Activity Area.

If an optimized resource allocation is possible, the warehouse operations manager, can accept these changes and the resources will be reassigned in the EWM system so that they will receive workload to execute from the new area.

Joule-enabled with custom EWM Joule Skills

Further more the current version of the Application provides Joule support for Warehouse Operations Management with the following Joule Skills:

- Joule Skill 1: Current Workload Analysis: Provide a comprehensive analysis of the current workload associated with picking and packing operations, considering the current resource allocation across different warehouse areas, as well as dependent scheduling of packing activities.
- Joule Skill 2: Provide Optimized Resource Allocation: Simulate an optimal workforce allocation strategy to mitigate bottlenecks and criticalities within the warehouse operations, to avoid shipping delays.
- Joule Skill 3: Accept Optimized Resource Allocation: Accept the optimization results and reassign the resources in EWM to the new areas.   

Coming soon an AI Agent will be introduce that autonomously orchestrates workforce allocation (monitored by the supervisor).

For more Information on this Application & AI functionality please contact SAP Services (EWMServices@sap.com).
